title: FirstFT: Senate approves same-sex and interracial marriage legislation
text:
The US Senate has approved legislation which protects the right to same-sex marriage after concerns that it might be at risk of being overturned by the conservative majority of justices on the Supreme Court.

The bill passed the upper chamber of Congress by a vote of 61-36. It won bipartisan support as 12 Republicans joined Democrats to adopt the measure, which also enshrines recognition for interracial marriages, saying couples are protected from discrimination regardless of their “sex, race, ethnicity or national origin”.

The legislation now heads to the House of Representatives, where it is expected to be approved and sent to President Joe Biden's desk for his signature.

The need for the legislation was sparked by the Supreme Court's decision in June to overturn Roe vs Wade, which established the right to an abortion. Justice Clarence Thomas, the longest-serving member of the court, has suggested the court should revisit other landmark rulings — including Obergefell vs Hodges, the 2015 case recognising same-sex marriage.

The legislation passed by the Senate would pre-empt any such decision. “Today, the US Senate stood up to Justice Clarence Thomas's radical, regressive vision for America,” said Dick Durbin, the Democratic chair of the Senate judiciary committee.

Dig deeper: In the ultimate coup for the right, it's Justice Thomas's Supreme Court now.

Five more stories in the news

1. US militia leader convicted of seditious conspiracy Stewart Rhodes, founder of the Oath Keepers, a rightwing militia group, faces up to 20 years in jail after being convicted of seditious conspiracy in connection with the attack on the US Capitol on January 6 2021. The conviction is an important victory for the Department of Justice which has arrested and charged hundreds of individuals accused of storming the Capitol last year. The Rhodes trial was among the most high-profile.

2. Fed officials in danger of splitting on rate rises, warn economists A united front among Federal Reserve officials is in danger of splintering as sharper divisions emerge among policymakers over how forcefully to squeeze the economy to tackle inflation, economists have warned. Fed watchers will look for more guidance from chair Jay Powell today, as he speaks at the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy.

3. US ambassador urges China not to interfere with protests The US envoy to China has urged Xi Jinping's administration not to interfere with peaceful demonstrations just as a Communist party security chief warned against “hostile” forces. “We believe that Chinese people have a right to protest peacefully, they have a right to make their views known, they have a right to be heard,” Ambassador Nicholas Burns said during a video call with the Chicago Council on Global Affairs.

4. Jiang Zemin dies Jiang, the former Chinese president who helped stabilise the world's most populous country after the Tiananmen Square massacre, has died aged 96. He served as general secretary of the ruling Communist party from 1989 to 2002 and, alongside Zhu Rongji, his premier, helped entrench the sweeping market-orientated reforms of Deng Xiaoping. Find out more.

5. UK ready to relax ringfencing rules on some banks The “ringfencing” of banks with retail and investment arms was introduced after the 2008 financial crash, but critics have said the rules are inefficient. Andrew Griffith, City minister, told the Financial Times' Global Banking Summit change was coming. “We can make the UK a better place to be a bank, to release some of that trapped capital over time around the ringfence,” he said.

For the very latest headlines, visit our liveblog.

The day ahead

US jobs: The labour department will release its latest job openings survey, which is expected to show that there were 10.3mn job openings in October, down from 10.7mn in September. Although the number of vacancies fell in August, a rebound in September pointed to a labour market that remains tight, despite efforts by the Federal Reserve to cool the economy with a string of aggressive rate rises. 

GDP: The US commerce department will provide a second estimate on the US's third-quarter gross domestic product, which is forecast to be a 2.7 per cent expansion, up 0.1 percentage points from the initial estimate. 

Corporate earnings: Software company Salesforce is expected to post earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $7.8bn for the third quarter, compared with 47 cents a share on revenue of $6.9bn during the same period last year. Other groups reporting earnings today include Calvin Klein owner PVH, pet store Petco and food processor Hormel.

Fifa World Cup: It's the final matches in groups C and D today. Tunisia play France and Australia take on Denmark, while Saudi Arabia face Mexico and Argentina play Poland.

  • The US beat Iran last night to qualify for the round of 16, but it was the end of an emotional journey for the Iranian team.

What else we're reading

A year of pain: investors struggle in new era of higher rates In November 2021, Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell called time on an era of super-cheap money, throwing out the rule book global investors had used for more than a decade. One year on, fund managers are still adjusting to a brave new world.

‘It just kinda went crazy': FTX's lavish spending Sam Bankman-Fried said his motive in building FTX was to maximise the amount he could donate to charity over his lifetime. Yet behind the grand promises was an environment where senior executives in their late 20s and early 30s splashed millions of dollars on everything from sport sponsorship deals to luxury homes.

  • Doesn't anyone do due diligence any more? It's been a lousy month for the reputation of professional investing, writes Brooke Masters, with the Theranos and FTX dramas showing a broad failure to ask enough questions before handing over cash.

How to think about policy in a polycrisis It is convenient to think about the world in intellectual silos, focusing in turn on macroeconomics, finance, politics, the environment, etc. This may work well in a reasonably stable world, writes Martin Wolf, but surely it's time we think about how these interact.

Why Rishi Sunak is struggling to impose his authority Sebastian Payne explains why the new prime minister is already facing multiple challenges to his authority from rebel Conservative MPs.

Chinese companies head for Singapore to hedge against geopolitical risk As US-China relations deteriorate, more Chinese businesses are “Singapore-washing”. As many as 500 Chinese companies have quietly redomiciled or registered in Singapore over the past 12 months in a bid to hedge against rising geopolitical risk.
